Acton Town: Alphabetically, the first tube station on the network. (credit The Nudge)
Aldgate: Is built directly on top of a vast plague pit, where 1000's of bodies are apparently buried. No-one knows quite how many. (credit The Nudge)
Aldgate East: While engineers worked on lowering the track level, trains kept running as the existing line was precariously suspended on wooden trestles from the ceiling. (credit The Nudge)
Alperton: Has the only remaining wooden escalators on the network, bricked up behind a wall. (credit The Nudge)
Amersham: The highest station on the network, at a solid 147m above sea level. (credit The Nudge)
Angel: Has the Underground's longest escalator at 60m/197ft, with a vertical rise of 27.5m. In fact, they're the 4th longest in Western Europe. (credit The Nudge)
Archway: Hidden in the green & cream tiling pattern at Archway station, there are black arches. (credit The Nudge)
Arnos Grove: The design of the station – which is Grade II listed – was inspired by the Stockholm Public Library. (credit The Nudge)
Arsenal: The only station in the UK named after a football team. (credit The Nudge)
Baker Street: Has the most platforms of any tube station – 10. (credit The Nudge)
Balham: Balham is the only Underground station that doesn't have any of the letters of the word ‘underground' in it. (credit The Nudge)
Bank: Has the most entrances/exits of any tube station with 12. (credit The Nudge)
Barbican: The tube's first rail disaster happened here – 4 people died in 1866 and the trains were running again within half an hour. (credit The Nudge)
Barking: Currently has a direct freight service running 7,500 miles direct to & from the city of Yiwu, on China's east coast. (credit The Nudge)
Barkingside: Is the only station on the network with an ornate, medieval-style Hammerbeam Roof (usually only used in great halls or cathedrals). (credit The Nudge)
Barons Court: Mahatma Gandhi lived at 20 Barons Court Road, a few yards from the station, while studying law. (credit The Nudge)
Bayswater: Was originally called Queen's Road (Bayswater), but the name was changed to avoid confusion with Queensway, which was also called Queen's Road. And the kicker? There is no Queen's Road in Kensington. (credit The Nudge)
Becontree: When Beacontree was first built in the interwar period, it was the largest housing estate in the world – and a railway station was built specifically for it. (credit The Nudge)
Belsize Park: Belsize Park has a sign claiming that the stairs have 219 steps, but there are actually 189. (credit The Nudge)
Bermondsey: Is a perfect anagram of “Snob Remedy”. (credit The Nudge)
Bethnal Green: In Anglo Saxon, Bethnal Green literally means “happy corner”. (credit The Nudge)
Blackfriars: In January 2014 the Blackfriars Railway Bridge became the world's largest solar-powered bridge, having been covered with 4,400 photovoltaic panels providing up to half of the energy for the station. (credit The Nudge)
Blackhorse Road: Despite the black horses depicted in station murals, it's actually named after a nearby black house. (credit The Nudge)
Bond Street: Harry Selfridge drew up proposals for a direct subway connecting the station to his store, and for the station to be renamed ‘Selfridges'. The proposals were declined. (credit The Nudge)
Borough: As an architectural shortcut, it was essentially a replica of Kennington station when it was first built. (credit The Nudge)
Boston Manor: Thanks to its Art Deco design, the station appeared on a postage stamp in 2013. (credit The Nudge)
Bounds Green: Name-dropped in the lyrics to Has it Come to This? by The Streets. (credit The Nudge)
Bow Road: The steepest gradient on the tube network at 3.6%. Insanity. (credit The Nudge)
Brent Cross: Brent Cross station was named after the shopping centre when it opened nearby in 1976, not the other way around. (credit The Nudge)
Brixton: There's a mural in the station of a pyramid of bricks, which is a visual pun of a ton of bricks (or a ‘bricks ton'). (credit The Nudge)
Bromley-by-Bow: In EastEnders, the fictional Walford East tube station takes the place of Bromley-by-Bow. (credit The Nudge)
Buckhurst Hill: The only through station in zones 1 to 6 on the Underground to be in a zone on its own – passengers travelling from the station leaving in either direction must cross a zone boundary. (credit The Nudge)
Burnt Oak: The first ever Tesco was opened just down the road from the station, in 1929. The tins had no labels to keep cost down. (credit The Nudge)
Caledonian Road: Named after an asylum for Scottish children built nearby in 1828. Not as in mental asylum, but as in safe asylum. To be clear. (credit The Nudge)
Camden Town: Because the station is so busy at weekends, they're planning on rebuilding it, and demolishing Camden Market in the process (don't panic though, that doesn't include the Stables Market, The Lock Market, the Inverness Street market, etc.). (credit The Nudge)
Canada Water: Designed by the same architect as the Millennium Dome. Who was clearly copying his own homework. (credit The Nudge)
Canary Wharf: The busiest station to serve a single line, and it's had at least one wedding celebrated in it. (credit The Nudge)
Canning Town: There was another Canning Town station north of Barking road, but when the DLR came along, instead of adding a platform to the existing station, they simply demolished the whole thing and built a new one from scratch. (credit The Nudge)
Cannon Street: The name first appears as ‘Candelwrichstrete Street' in 1190. The name was shortened over 60 times, and eventually settled on Cannon Street in the 17th century. It is therefore not related to the firearms. (credit The Nudge)
Canons Park: Named after Cannons, a vast house built on the site in 1724 at the cost of £28m (adjusted for inflation). It was demolished and sold off brick by brick 20 years later. And therefore not related to the firearms, either. (credit The Nudge)
Chalfont & Latimer: The longest single journey between neighbouring stations: 9 mins on average to Chesham. (credit The Nudge)
Chalk Farm: The Roundhouse next door used to be a railway turntable servicing the station. (credit The Nudge)
Chancery Lane: In the '70s, the former air raid shelter built underneath the station was turned into a telephone exchange with 200 staff, its own restaurant, bar, and games room, all 200ft below the surface. (credit The Nudge)
Charing Cross: Modern day Charing Cross is an amalgamation of two old stations: Trafalgar Square and Strand. (credit The Nudge)
Chesham: Furthest away from any other station, at 3.8mi to the nearest neighbour. (credit The Nudge)
Chigwell: Serves the town of Chigwell, which Charles Dickens described as “the greatest place in the world”. (credit The Nudge)
Chiswick Park: Once known as Acton Green – the name was changed due to there being 7 other Acton stations already. (credit The Nudge)
Chorleywood: The name literally means “peasant's wood” (and currently has one of the highest qualities of life in the country). (credit The Nudge)
Clapham Common: For 2 weeks in September 2016, all of the adverts used in the station were replaced by photos of cats. (credit The Nudge)
Clapham North: Was the test site for the UK's first underground farm, housed in its deep level bomb shelter. The company now grows food under Clapham High Street. (credit The Nudge)
Clapham South: The station was originally to have been called ‘Nightingale Lane' and this name still exists hidden behind the blue bars on the platform roundels. (credit The Nudge)
Cockfosters: Being the final/first station on the line, it has a tunnel designed to mirror the one at Uxbridge at the opposing end of the line. (credit The Nudge)
Colindale: Was frequently used by T.E. Lawrence (AKA Lawrence of Arabia), who used the pen name ‘Colin Dale' during his journalistic career. (credit The Nudge)
Colliers Wood: The pub opposite is named after the architect who designed the station itself, Charles Holden. In fact, he designed a great many stations in his time. (credit The Nudge)
Covent Garden: London Underground's standard £4.80 single cash fare for the journey between here and Leicester Square equates to £29.81 a mile, making the fare for this particular journey more expensive per mile than the Orient Express. (credit The Nudge)
Croxley: A story is told of how a year after the opening of the station in 1926, a group of ladies was directed to it by Croxley's policeman P.C. Haggar. He bade them a cheery “Good-night” – to learn shortly afterwards that they were a band of suffragettes who had set fire to the new station. (credit The Nudge)
Dagenham East: Was the site of a rail crash in 1958 due to fog – and the train that caused it is still active on the Severn Valley Railway. (credit The Nudge)
Dagenham Heathway: Despite being smaller, and having fewer platforms, gets twice the number of passengers per year as Dagenham East. (credit The Nudge)
Debden: Debden station was the setting for the Victorian ballad “The Chigwell Stationmaster's Wife”. Not Chigwell. (credit The Nudge)
Dollis Hill: Dollis Hill played a part in the Second World War, as the code-breaking computer used at Bletchley Park was built here. (credit The Nudge)
Ealing Broadway: Platforms 8 & 9 still contain some of the pre-roundel logo designs. (credit The Nudge)
Ealing Common: Has a heptagonal ticket hall, one of only two on the network. (credit The Nudge)
Earl's Court: The site of the last remaining blue police telephone box – radios took over in the 1970s. (credit The Nudge)
East Acton: Not actually in the borough of Acton, it just took the name to be part of the trend – there are seven Acton stations on the network. (credit The Nudge)
East Finchley: Jerry Springer was born in the station during an air raid in WW2. (credit The Nudge)
East Ham: Between 1851 when the station wan built, and 1911, East Ham's population grew by 7585%. (credit The Nudge)
East Putney: On 1 April 1994, it was sold to London Underground for the princely sum of £1. (credit The Nudge)
Eastcote: Was originally called Ascot. (credit The Nudge)
Edgware: Was supposed to connect to Mill Hill East, and you can still see the disused track that leads to it... (credit The Nudge)
Edgware Road: Has a “living wall” wall of plants outside the station, the only one in the underground network. (credit The Nudge)
Elephant & Castle: Named after a nearby pub, which itself was name-dropped in Shakespeare's Twelfth Night. (credit The Nudge)
Elm Park: Celebrations to mark the opening of the station in 1935 included a performance by the Dagenham Girl Pipers – they performed in Nazi Germany around the same time, and Hitler is said to have remarked: “I wish I had a band like that”. (credit The Nudge)
Embankment: Has a huge, empty substation attached to it, abandoned since 1957. Called ‘Pages Walk' it's behind a blast door in the station, and is so large it's been proposed as a possible nightclub location. (credit The Nudge)
Epping: Has the largest public London Underground station car park with 519 spaces. It's usually still full by around 6.30am each day though. (credit The Nudge)
Euston: Has a bench made from 450million year old stone outside of it. (credit The Nudge)
Euston Square: Was the place that the very first piece of work on the underground – or any underground railway on earth – took place. A shaft was sunk in January 1860 there. (credit The Nudge)
Fairlop: The only tube station named after a tree. Apart from, technically Burnt Oak. (credit The Nudge)
Farringdon: Originally designed to transport livestock to Smithfield market – there are still cattle ramps onto the street West Smithfield for this purpose. (credit The Nudge)
Finchley Central: Has an original copy of the Harry Beck Tube map on display; he lived nearby and used the station frequently. (credit The Nudge)
Finchley Road: Analysis of earth removed when tunnelling towards the station revealed that its site was the southern limit of a glacier which covered Britain in one of the Ice Ages. (credit The Nudge)
Finsbury Park: Due to confusion with popular duelling site Finsbury Field, when it opened the station was decorated with mosaics of duelling pistols. They're still there today. (credit The Nudge)
Fulham Broadway: It's the station in 1998's Sliding Doors where reality changes because of a missed train. (credit The Nudge)
Gants Hill: The easternmost station to be entirely below ground on the London Underground network. (credit The Nudge)
Gloucester Road: Has a disused platform that's used as a permanent art exhibition. ...Technically making it a used platform. (credit The Nudge)
Golders Green: Was the last station on the Northern line to retain semaphore signals, replaced in 1950. (credit The Nudge)
Goldhawk Road: The line running through Goldhawk Road station was active as early as 1864, yet no station opened there until 1914. (credit The Nudge)
Goodge Street: Not actually on Goodge Street – it's closer to both Tottenham Street and Whitfield Street. (credit The Nudge)
Grange Hill: Destroyed by a V1 “doodlebug” bomb during WW2. (credit The Nudge)
Great Portland Street: Despite having three lines run through it, it only has one pair of tracks, making it one of the most intensely used parts of the network. (credit The Nudge)
Green Park: Named after the park, which itself is said to have originally been a swampy burial ground for lepers from nearby St James' hospital. (credit The Nudge)
Greenford: Used its original, century-old wooden escalator right up until 2014. (credit The Nudge)
Gunnersbury: On 8 December 1954 the station was damaged by a tornado which ripped off the roof and injured six people. (credit The Nudge)
Hainault: The lifts are the shallowest on the London Underground network, having a descent of just 0.67 metres. (credit The Nudge)
Hammersmith: Technically, it's two stations – one District/Piccadilly, one Hammersmith & City/Circle. And to get from one to the other without walking would require a minimum of 10 stops and 3 changes. (credit The Nudge)
Hampstead: The deepest station on the line, at 58m below ground – that's more than Nelson's Column. (credit The Nudge)
Hanger Lane: In a reversal of most other stations, it has to be entered underground, but the station itself is entirely above ground. (credit The Nudge)
Harlesden: Is almost twice as far away from Harlesden town centre as Willesden Junction is. (credit The Nudge)
Harrow & Wealdstone: Technically the oldest station on the network: the mainline station was built in 1837, predating Baker Street by 24 years. It was opened for Underground trains in 1917. (credit The Nudge)
Harrow-on-the-Hill: It's actually on Green Hill, north of Harrow Hill. (credit The Nudge)
Hatton Cross: On its opening in 1975, Hatton Cross was one of 279 active stations on the London Underground, the highest ever total; the number of stations in the network has since decreased to 270. (credit The Nudge)
Heathrow Terminal 4: It is the only station on the network to have one-way train service. (credit The Nudge)
Heathrow Terminal 5: Despite being underground, the ceiling is made from laminate panels, allowing natural daylight to illuminate it. (credit The Nudge)
Heathrow Terminals 2 & 3: Back when it opened in 1977, it was the first time that an airport had been directly served by an underground railway system. (credit The Nudge)
Hendon Central: When it was first built, the station was surrounded by fields – the town was essentially constructed around it. (credit The Nudge)
High Barnet: Is situated on the hill that's thought to be the inspiration for the nursery rhyme The Grand Old Duke of York. (credit The Nudge)
High Street Kensington: Once had a waiting room for passengers who didn't fancy the platform. This was changed into a break room for drivers. (credit The Nudge)
Highbury & Islington: Despite being hit by a V-1 flying bomb during WW2, the original station building stayed in use until it was demolished in 1960. (credit The Nudge)
Highgate: The disused platforms and tunnels have sometimes been used for filming and have appeared in several productions including the feature film Paperhouse, and the television series EastEnders and Waking the Dead. (credit The Nudge)
Hillingdon: The name Hillingdon is Middle English, and means “Hill's hill”. (credit The Nudge)
Holborn: Was used to store British Museum treasures during WW2. A newspaper even offered a cash reward to anyone who dared spend the night there in the 60s amid rumours of a mummy ghost – nobody took them up on it. (credit The Nudge)
Holland Park: Built with a flat roof in order for a retail unit to be built on top of it. 115 years later, there is still no retail unit. (credit The Nudge)
Holloway Road: Used to have a spiral escalator (which is now stored in the Acton depot). (credit The Nudge)
Hornchurch: In the 80 years since the station was built, Hornchurch's population increased by x43 times. (credit The Nudge)
Hounslow Central: Replaced Hounslow Town tube station, which was open for just three years. (credit The Nudge)
Hounslow East: In the 1700s, the nearby heath was notorious for successful Highwaymen – which is a neat coincidence, because Hounslow East is a perfect anagram for ‘outlaws shone'. (credit The Nudge)
Hounslow West: Due to the nearby military barracks, Winston Churchill used to frequent this station. (credit The Nudge)
Hyde Park Corner: The station is located entirely underground, with no surface presence – though there is an old station building that has since been used as a pizza restaurant and a hotel. The lifts from that building are now ventilation shafts. (credit The Nudge)
Ickenham: Said to be haunted each Christmas since the '50s by a woman in a red scarf, who was electrocuted there. She flails her arms, apparently. (credit The Nudge)
Kennington: Stay on a terminating Northern line train heading south at Kennington and you'll go round in a loop, arriving back at Kennington and heading north. People who are drunk/asleep have been known to end up in Edgware, rather than in Morden. (credit The Nudge)
Kensal Green: In December 2006, the station was hit (or at least grazed) by a tornado. (credit The Nudge)
Kensington (Olympia): The station's old name, ‘Addison Road Station' still appears sculpted into a wall on the eastern pedestrian exit. (credit The Nudge)
Kentish Town: There used to be a South Kentish Town tube station down the road. It became disused after strike action from the power station supplying it caused it to shut down, and they simply never re-opened it, even when the power came back on. (credit The Nudge)
Kenton: Both Kenton, Kennington, and Kensington are, by total coincidence, derived from the same name – Keninton. (credit The Nudge)
Kew Gardens: The Tube's track is crossed by Kew Gardens Station Footbridge, a Grade II listed feature in its own right – it was designed specifically to prevent smoke from steam trains getting into people's clothing. (credit The Nudge)
Kilburn: At the turn of the 20th Century the station was going to be replaced with “a type of subterranean monorail roller coaster”, but plans were (sadly) abandoned. (credit The Nudge)
Kilburn Park: The first station to be designed around escalators, rather than lifts. (credit The Nudge)
King's Cross St Pancras: Has the shortest lift shaft on the network, at just 2.3 metres. (credit The Nudge)
Kingsbury: Was originally on the Metropolitan Line, before being transferred to the Bakerloo Line, and finally landing on the Jubilee Line. (credit The Nudge)
Knightsbridge: Suffered huge congestion problems, which were solved when they built an exit specifically for Harrods. (credit The Nudge)
Ladbroke Grove: Was originally called Notting Hill, but the name was changed to avoid confusion with Notting Hill Gate. There's now a movement to change the name to Portobello Road, despite the fact that it's not on Portobello Road. It's on Ladbroke Grove. (credit The Nudge)
Lambeth North: Has been called Kennington Road, Westminster Bridge Road, and finally Lambeth North. (credit The Nudge)
Lancaster Gate: Despite its name, the station is close to the Marlborough Gate entrance to Hyde Park/Kensington Gardens, about 300m to the east of the Lancaster Gate entrance. (credit The Nudge)
Latimer Road: Is actually located half a kilometer away from Latimer Road. (credit The Nudge)
Leicester Square: On all four platforms, film sprockets are painted down the entire length and on the top and bottom of the display area (blue on the Piccadilly line platforms, and black on the Northern line platforms), due to the four premiere cinemas in Leicester Square. (credit The Nudge)
Leyton: Is home to one of the most accident-prone stretches of the Underground network: the line between Leyton & Stratford has had several fatal crashes, including one in 1953 in which 12 people died, the worst accident on the tube at the time. (credit The Nudge)
Leytonstone: Features 17 mosaics of Alfred Hitchcock films & famous moments. (credit The Nudge)
Liverpool Street: Built on the original site of the Bethlehem (Bedlam) mental asylum. (credit The Nudge)
London Bridge: Is the only station on the entire London Underground network with the word “London” in its name. (credit The Nudge)
Loughton: The station was originally built so that City workers would have easy access to Epping Forest. (credit The Nudge)
Maida Vale: When Maida Vale station opened on 6 June 1915 it was entirely staffed by women due to shortages of male staff in the war. (credit The Nudge)
Manor House: Of its street-level entrances, three are in Hackney, and one is in Haringey. (credit The Nudge)
Mansion House: Has all five vowels in its name. (credit The Nudge)
Marble Arch: The marble arch opposite the station was originally going to be the entrance to Buckingham Palace. (credit The Nudge)
Marylebone: Very nearly wasn't built because it might have disturbed the cricket played at Lords. It took an act of parliament to finally push construction through. (credit The Nudge)
Mile End: Is named so because it's exactly one mile from the eastern boundary of The City of London. (credit The Nudge)
Mill Hill East: Features a Creditduct in which trains travel 18m above ground – the highest point on the Underground network. (credit The Nudge)
Monument: Its original name, Eastcheap, lasted precisely one month before it was changed to Monument. (credit The Nudge)
Moor Park: Has a “secret” unmarked entrance adjacent to a golf course. (credit The Nudge)
Moorgate: Has a virtually unknown second underground network/line which starts here – the Northern City Line runs from Moorgate to Finsbury Park, and is't run by TFL. (credit The Nudge)
Morden: Is the start of the longest tunnel on the Underground network, running 27.8 kilometres (17.3 mi) to East Finchley Credit the Bank branch. (credit The Nudge)
Mornington Crescent: Is the subject of a deliberately incomprehensible gameshow on BBC Radio 4, in which there are no rules. (credit The Nudge)
Neasden: The Tube celebrated its centenary here in 1963 with a series of events including a parade of underground trains. (credit The Nudge)
Newbury Park: The bus shelter attached to it is Grade II listed. The station isn't. (credit The Nudge)
North Acton: Station staff regularly participate in Transport for London's annual Underground in Bloom competition, and in 2010 won first prize in the Fruit and Vegetable category, for their sweetcorn and strawberries. (credit The Nudge)
North Ealing: Is not actually north of Ealing, but east of it. (credit The Nudge)
North Greenwich: Despite its name, it is not in the area historically known as North Greenwich, on the Isle of Dogs, north of the River Thames; an entirely different North Greenwich station used to be there, between 1872 and 1926. (credit The Nudge)
North Harrow: Has been awarded the “Best Customer Service” trophy at the London Transport Awards – no surprise, the station master is called James Bond. (credit The Nudge)
North Wembley: The safest tube station on the entire network, according to the MET. (credit The Nudge)
Northfields: The 5th president of the US, John Quincey Adams lived next to the site of the station for two years. (credit The Nudge)
Northolt: Northala park next door features four man-made hills, constructed from the waste rubble of Wembley stadium. (credit The Nudge)
Northwick Park: Is only 350m from Kenton station, making it the closest tube station pair outside zone 1. (credit The Nudge)
Northwood: Is actually at a higher level than Northwood Hills. (credit The Nudge)
Northwood Hills: Before it opened in 1933, there was a competition to name it. This was, apparently, the winning entry, despite the station being lower than Northwood. (credit The Nudge)
Notting Hill Gate: The reason it's called Notting Hill Gate is because it was literally a gate: it used to be a toll road. (credit The Nudge)
Oakwood: The booking hall originally had a plaque claiming that the station occupied ‘the highest point in Europe in a direct line west of the Ural Mountains of Russia', which is a very strange way of saying that it's 300 feet above sea level. (credit The Nudge)
Old Street: It's buried in soil so acidic that the cast iron tunnel linings had to be replaced in the '90s due to corrosion. (credit The Nudge)
Osterley: This building replaced the earlier Osterley & Spring Grove station, 300 metres away, which is now Osterley Bookshop. Inside the bookshop the archway to the platforms is still visible, but blocked off, and the platforms behind are still in place. (credit The Nudge)
Oval: The first railway station to employ electrified tracks in London. (credit The Nudge)
Oxford Circus: In 1969, to celebrate the opening of the new Victoria Line, The Queen ‘took the wheel' of a train, and drove it from Green Park to Oxford Circus. (credit The Nudge)
Paddington: The track running towards Bayswater passes under 23-24 Leinster Road – a facade constructed to match neighbouring terrace houses. disguising where the original house was demolished to allow a gap in the tube system for steam trains to er …let off steam. (credit The Nudge)
Park Royal: The station plaforms aren't actually level – they slope up from south to north. (credit The Nudge)
Parsons Green: Is an anagram of “passenger ron”. (credit The Nudge)
Perivale: Is an anagram of “rail peve”. (credit The Nudge)
Piccadilly Circus: A world map in the station ticket hall, dating from the 1920s, contains a linear clock that shows the time in all parts of the world. (credit The Nudge)
Pimlico: Originally named after Ben Pimlico, a Hoxton brewer famous for his nut brown ale. It was so insanely popular with the residents of Pimlico, the place became named after him. (credit The Nudge)
Pinner: In 2009, a Pyrenean Mountain Dog named Rufus became a minor celebrity for his daily commute from Pinner to Baker Street due to his enormous size. (credit The Nudge)
Plaistow: Prior to the station being put in, Plaistow was “a whole day's coach ride” to Westminster. Afterwards, it took less than half an hour. (credit The Nudge)
Preston Road: Was originally named “Preston Road Halt for Uxendon and Kenton”, which would have made it easily the longest name on the line, and the only one with an actual instruction. (credit The Nudge)
Putney Bridge: Technically not in Putney – it's on the Fulham side of the Thames. (credit The Nudge)
Queen's Park: The site of the only “carriage shed” on the tube line: a wooden garden shed-like tunnel that you pass through on the northward part of your journey. (credit The Nudge)
Queensbury: The name Queensbury did not, when it was chosen, refer to any pre-existing area. It was coined by analogy with the adjacent Kingsbury station. (credit The Nudge)
Queensway: Named Queen's Road originally (because Queen Victoria was born nearby), but people thought that ‘lacked distinctiveness', so was changed. (credit The Nudge)
Ravenscourt Park: The least Instagrammed station in London, with zero posts for the whole of 2016. (credit The Nudge)
Rayners Lane: When the station first opened, there was only one single house nearby, owned by a farmer named Daniel Rayner. The station was duly called Rayner's Lane. (credit The Nudge)
Redbridge: During WW2, the train tunnels at Redbridge were used as an aircraft parts factory. (credit The Nudge)
Regent's Park: A parliamentary law originally declared that no station could be built at the current site – it was overturned, but there's still no surface station here. (credit The Nudge)
Richmond: Built from Portland Stone – a Jurassic era limestone from Dorset used in the construction of Buckingham Palace, St. Paul's Cathederal, and the UN Building in New York. (credit The Nudge)
Rickmansworth: Is a surprising hub for film locations: scenes for both Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark, and the Last Crusade were filmed literally two minutes north of the station, as well as Bridget Jones and the Edge of Reason, and Blackadder. (credit The Nudge)
Roding Valley: The quietest tube station on the line, each year transporting the same number of passengers as Waterloo does in one day. (credit The Nudge)
Royal Oak: Named after a nearby pub (still there, but now called The Porchester). (credit The Nudge)
Ruislip: Due to the convoluted tracks, it's actually possible to reverse trains here, but it takes up both platforms, so it's not done at peak hours. (credit The Nudge)
Ruislip Gardens: The station achieved poetic immortality in Poet Laureate John Betjeman's poem Middlesex. (credit The Nudge)
Ruislip Manor: Suffered heavy aerial bombardment by the Luftwaffe during WW2, due to its proximity to RAF Northholt. (credit The Nudge)
Russell Square: The sign lists the number of steps as 175. There as in fact, 171. Quite why no-one double checked is a mystery. (credit The Nudge)
Seven Sisters: Named after seven elm trees which have stood in the neighbourhood since the 1730s. The current trees were planted by five families of seven sisters. (credit The Nudge)
Shepherd's Bush: The station has no lifts because, due to nearby utilities, they would cost £100m to install. Adjusted for inflation, that's about half the cost of the construction of entire Metropolitan Line. (credit The Nudge)
Shepherd's Bush Market: Until 2008, it was also called Shepherd's Bush until it was renamed to avoid confusion. (credit The Nudge)
Sloane Square: The River Westbourne literally runs through the station – it was redirected through its own little bridge suspended over the main platform. (credit The Nudge)
Snaresbrook: Most of the station's Victorian features remain today, including brick buildings, extensive cast iron, and timber canopies. (credit The Nudge)
South Ealing: Has all five vowels in its name. (credit The Nudge)
South Harrow: The train actually travels over a marsh north of the station. It crosses it Credit aquaduct. (credit The Nudge)
South Kensington: Between South Kensington and Knightsbridge, the tube steers away from following the road above it in order to avoid a large plague pit. (credit The Nudge)
South Kenton: Its platform was built too high for the trains, and never corrected. (credit The Nudge)
South Ruislip: The concrete, glass and granite chip frieze in the booking hall is one of the earliest public works by glass artist, Henry Haig, who would go onto become one of Britain's most revered stained glass artists. (credit The Nudge)
South Wimbledon: Opening in 1926, the originally proposed name was Merton Grove, but it was renamed South Wimbledon to try and sound classier. (credit The Nudge)
South Woodford: The only station in which the name on the station's own roundels is different to the official name – they call it South Woodford (George Lane). (credit The Nudge)
Southfields: The station platform undergoes a makeover each year to coincide with the Wimbledon tennis tournament. Wimbledon station doesn't. (credit The Nudge)
Southgate: When it first opened, local residents were given a free return ticket to Piccadilly Circus to encourage them to use the service. (credit The Nudge)
Southwark: Southwark Station's blue cone wall, built as part of the Jubilee line extension's new generation of stations, was inspired by an 1816 stage set for The Magic Flute. (credit The Nudge)
St James's Park: Is a Grade 1 listed building, making station improvements considerably difficult. (credit The Nudge)
St John's Wood: Famously, the only station on the Underground network not to share any letters with the word “mackerel”. (credit The Nudge)
St Paul's: During the Second World War, the electricity grid control room for the entire of London and Southeast England was housed here, in the lift shaft. (credit The Nudge)
Stamford Brook: The first tube station to have an automatic ticket barrier installed on 5 January 1964. (credit The Nudge)
Stanmore: Was a secret outstation for Bletchley Park during WW2 – in fact, the crosswords decorating the station house are a reference to the test WW2 codebreakers had to pass to qualify for consideration: completing the Times crossword in under 12minutes. (credit The Nudge)
Stepney Green: A Tudor-era bowling ball was unearthed during the Crossrail excavations under the station. (credit The Nudge)
Stockwell: Just below the station platforms, there is an air raid shelter comprised of two tunnels, both six times the length of the platrforms themselves. They're currently used as a secure archive. (credit The Nudge)
Stonebridge Park: The booking hall is the only original feature – the rest has been destroyed by WW2 boming, and two major fires. (credit The Nudge)
Stratford: Has the shortest escalator on the network, with a vertical rise of 4.1m. (credit The Nudge)
Sudbury Hill: The station is said to have one of the highest levels of ‘pigeon customers' in the whole London Underground network. Staff often have to chase large numbers of the birds out of the ticket hall. (credit The Nudge)
Sudbury Town: Has a barometer hanging above the ticket hall from the 1930s – in fact, it's the only station with a barometer still in it. (credit The Nudge)
Swiss Cottage: Named after the nearby pub. (credit The Nudge)
Temple: On the columns at Temple station, there are small temple-shaped emblems at the bases. (credit The Nudge)
Theydon Bois: Is the only part of Theydon Bois that has street lighting – the rest of the town has none in order to maintain ambiance. (credit The Nudge)
Tooting Bec: Has a crater on Mars named after it. (credit The Nudge)
Tooting Broadway: The big statue of Edward VII at the entrance was paid for entirely by the public when it was made in 1911. (credit The Nudge)
Tottenham Court Road: Was originally called Oxford Street (before Oxford Circus opened). (credit The Nudge)
Tottenham Hale: Has been the site of no less than five collisions & derailments. (credit The Nudge)
Totteridge & Whetstone: Was originally named ‘Whetstone and Totteridge', owing to the fact that it is in Whetstone. But the name was switched, for reasons we still can't tell. (credit The Nudge)
Tower Hill: King Henry VIII beheaded noble traitors to the crown and two of his wives here. Not like, in the station, but next door to it. (credit The Nudge)
Tufnell Park: On the service board at Tufnell Park station you'll find ‘Poetry Corner', the station staff's daily selection of poetry by local residents, school children and famous poets, ‘giving passengers something to read while they're waiting for the lifts'. (credit The Nudge)
Turnham Green: Wheeler's Florist, based directly outside the station, has provided flowers for Bond & Batman movies. Which, apparently, had flowers in them. (credit The Nudge)
Turnpike Lane: The name ‘Turnpike Lane' refers to a toll gate erected there in 1767. And of course, the tube barriers there now techincally are a toll gate, meaning the name is still accurate. (credit The Nudge)
Upminster: The speed of sound was first accurately measured from the church next to the station. (credit The Nudge)
Upminster Bridge: Displayed a swastika in its ticket hall when it was built in 1934. They took it down a few years later for some reason or another. (credit The Nudge)
Upney: The Gunpowder Plot was hatched in a manor house next to the station. (credit The Nudge)
Upton Park: The station's name is cockney slang for crazy (because they're ‘two stops short of Barking'). (credit The Nudge)
Uxbridge: Being the final/first station on the line, has a tunnel designed to mirror the one at Cockfosters at the opposing end of the line. (credit The Nudge)
Vauxhall: Thanks to the creamery next door, it used to run daily ‘milk trains' entirely filled with the white stuff. They would pull into the station, and pour their contents into a discharge pipe that led directly to the creamery. (credit The Nudge)
Victoria: Plays a key role in Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Earnest – the main character was discovered as a baby in a handbag in the station. (credit The Nudge)
Wanstead: The tunnels between Wanstead and Gants Hill to the east were turned into munitions factories during WW2. (credit The Nudge)
Warren Street: Used as the location for the 1972 British horror film, Death Line, which featured a family of cannibals living on the London Underground. (credit The Nudge)
Warwick Avenue: A song named after it by singer Duffy reached number 3 in the charts. (credit The Nudge)
Waterloo: Has 23 escalators, the most of any station on the network. (credit The Nudge)
Watford: Due to not being in the centre of town, has been threatened with closure since 1927. And it may well finally be closed in 2020. (credit The Nudge)
Wembley Central: Despite servicing Wembley Stadium, is only the 142nd busiest station on the line. (credit The Nudge)
Wembley Park: Was originally constructed to serve Wembley Pleasure Grounds, which were to be centrepieced by a tower taller than the Eiffel Tower. (credit The Nudge)
West Acton: The original 1923 station was rebuilt by 1940 – and it's now Grade II listed. (credit The Nudge)
West Brompton: The Overground lines here were built in 1866 (before the district line) as part of the West London Line – which was closed between 1940 and 1999 due to WWII bombing. (credit The Nudge)
West Finchley: Made predominantly from fittings taken from other stations in the North of England. The bridge apparently came from Yorkshire. (credit The Nudge)
West Ham: Has more platforms (8) than Charing Cross (6). (credit The Nudge)
West Hampstead: Was originally known as “West End” until the name was changed in order to avoid confusion with, well, the West End. (credit The Nudge)
West Harrow: Is, perhaps ironically, the station people travel to in order to get to Britain's biggest walking festival. (credit The Nudge)
West Kensington: Being next to the Queen's Club, it's 5x closer to a grass court tennis court than Wimbledon station. (credit The Nudge)
West Ruislip: The longest journey you can take without a change on the entire Underground network is the 37 miles from West Ruislip to Epping. (credit The Nudge)
Westbourne Park: Was the first station to be demolished. It was relocated in 1871. (credit The Nudge)
Westminster: Excavations for creating the deep level Jubilee line platforms caused Big Ben to move 35millimeters. Any more, and the tower would have cracked and possibly collapsed. (credit The Nudge)
White City: The architectural design of the station won an award at the 1951 Festival of Britain. (credit The Nudge)
Whitechapel: Whitechapel is the only place on the network where the Overground runs below the Underground. (credit The Nudge)
Willesden Green: When he was mayor, Ken Livingstone used to get the tube to work from here every day. (credit The Nudge)
Willesden Junction: In 1896 staff totalled 271, including 79 porters, 58 signalmen (in 14 signal boxes) and 58 shunters and yard foremen. (credit The Nudge)
Wimbledon: Laddie the Airedale Terrier was based at the station for six years, before retiring in 1956. During his time there, he collected £5,000 pounds in the change box on his back. (credit The Nudge)
Wimbledon Park: Despite being the closest station to the All England Club, is still closer to Wimbledon golf club than the tennis club. (credit The Nudge)
Wood Green: Gets name-dropped in songs by Razorlight (Los Angeles Waltz), Mark Knopfler (Junkie Doll), Pablo Gad (Black Before Creation), and Sway DaSafo (Up Your Speed). (credit The Nudge)
Wood Lane: Newest station on the network, opened in October 2008. (credit The Nudge)
Woodford: A wooden owl was put into the station's rafters during recent refurbishment as a reference to the owl sanctuary nearby. (credit The Nudge)
Woodside Park: Alphabetically, the last name on the entire Tube network. (credit The Nudge)
